text: As you can see, there is a difference in the position of where we put the dinner, which is a noun,
something you can put my in front of, my dinner, for instance,
and where we put it. It goes before, but a noun goes afterwards.
You may wonder why even would we want to use words like it?
Well, obviously, if you're talking, whether it's in English or in French,
you won't want to keep saying the dinner, because in the end you'll sound crazy,
saying, I'm going to prepare the dinner because I want to eat the dinner and dinner is going to be ready,
so I must get the dinner ready.
After a while in that sentence, you're going to want to replace the dinner with it, which is crucial.
So a word like it actually is a word that stands in for a noun.
So, for example, I want to prepare the dinner. One more time, let's do that.
But perhaps you've already talked about the fact that it is the dinner.
So maybe you've said, I'm going to prepare the dinner and I want to prepare it now.
Rather than saying, I'm going to prepare the dinner and I'm going to prepare the dinner now,
we wouldn't say that in English because you don't need to keep repeating it.
It's the same in French. You're going to want to use it instead.
You're going to want to replace the noun.
I want to prepare it.
Words such as it, and this is another grammatical term, are referred to in English as pronouns.
Now, this is not a particularly helpful term because it confuses people just like nouns do when they're not explained properly.
There is an easier way to understand what a pronoun is.
You can simply think of pronoun as being short for proxy noun.
A proxy is something that stands in place of something else.
It takes something else's place.
So the word it, it's a proxy for the dinner.
It's standing in place for it.
It's taking its place.
There are lots of proxy nouns in English, in French.
For instance, if we did not have the proxy noun, the pronoun I, it would be a big problem when we wanted to speak.
For instance, I would not be able to say that my name is Paul and I am teaching French.
Instead, I would be stuck by saying, my name is Paul and Paul is teaching French.
Because there would be no pronoun, no proxy noun to take the place of Paul.
So that's what these pronouns are.
They are words that sit in place of other words.
And they tend to be quite short because we use them to replace other words.
So, something like the dinner, we replace with it.
If we refer to something masculine in English, like my brother.
So we might say, my brother is here and he is happy.
You can see that he is sitting in place of my brother.
If he didn't exist, if this pronoun, this proxy noun didn't exist, we'd have to keep saying my brother.
My brother is here and my brother is happy and I'm going to spend time with my brother later.
So that's what pronouns are.
And as you'll see, they go in a different position than nouns do.
So, let's do that sentence more or less the same again.
But let's use it with can.
How would you say, I can prepare the dinner?
Je peux préparer le dîner.
We have the noun.
We have the noun.
It goes where it should go.
Again, as I said, a noun.
It's a word you can put my in front of, like my dinner.
My dinner is getting cold.
Now, let's see what happens when we replace dinner with it.
And we say, I can prepare it.
Je peux le préparer.
Thank you.
